It's not as bad as people say it is. I played quite a bit of Source and GO, and didn't really play the CS 1.6 or CZ so this was a new experience for me. 

The zombie mode is pretty legit since you can craft everything. The regular arcadish game style was something new and I feel that the microtransactions wouldn't make that big of a difference if you were simply good at shooters. There are quite a bit of game modes that me and my friends spent lots of time on.

The biggest things for me are the connection problems when you are trying to login (which are apparently being fixed) or the sound sfx/music that blares everytime you start the game because it doesn't save those settings apparently.

I'd definitely recommend at least taking a shot at this game once before all these negative reviews get to you.

Another free to play game has launched, and this one seems to be a mess. Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies is a take on the classic Counter-Strike game, adding zombies to the mix across 50 maps of play and dozens of modes. Unfortunately my first impressions with the game were poor - a confusing interface, an engine based on Half-Life 1, and poor performance all yielded a sub par result in game play.

For the most part the game seems to feature a variety of competitive mode of play where the traditional teams of Terrorists and Counter-Terrorists face off, but must also face the zombie threat as second thread. While the game has added new weapons and characters, including female characters to play as, it still contains a lot of the classic look and feel with maps such as de_dust and de_metro present. 
In terms of co-op, it appears there are two modes that support true co-op play. One is called "Human Scenario" where you face off against an "army of computer controlled opponents." I played a few minutes of it and basically shot at drones barely making a dent in the boss's health with 6 other people. The other mode is called Zombie Shelter, which appears to have some sort of strategy elements too it, but also an optional PvP element. Players must secure a shelter and then repel waves of zombies.

Well it's official, I have quite a game only 10 mins after starting it for the first time. It is a very confusing game because it is marketed as a version of Counter-Strike with Zombies, but acts more like a free to play shooter that happens to have similar textures that look worse than Counter-Strike: Source. Not only are the textures terrible, but it is not possible to run the game at any form of high resolution. I run all my games at 1600:900 which is absent from this game all together. Now for the gameplay, it is just flat out terrible. There are two types of games in this game all about micro-transactions, which are sort of traditional Counter-Strike PvP and some terrible version of infection game types. The normal Counter-Strike PvP feels terrible and is a poorly made PvP game type. It is just traditional deathmatch with very simple spawn points with conflict only being in the middle of a very boring designed map. Then the zombies PvP is the same thing as the traditional PvP, just with one team being zombies. It is exactly like any custom server you can play on with the traditional Counter-Strike: Source, and looks worse. The game is heavily based on it's micro-transactions, making it so guns are just "trials" that you have for like 1 to 3 days. This game is very poorly made and I do not plan to play again any time in the future.

While this is no doubt a game inspired by Valve's 2000 classic Counter-Strike 1.6 (which was originally a game developed by Turtle Rock Studios), there are some major differences that separates it in terms of gameplay.  First off, it's obviously an MMORPG where you collect item drops and ultimately spend most of your time seeking them.  For this game obviously, you collect weapons and mid-game healing/respawn supplies, as well as items used to craft other weapons/supplies.  These new weapons can be upgraded to be more efficient while you are shooting down other players and NPCs where it could be very useful.  Oh and don't worry, the entire arsenal from the original game are included.  The game DOES offer a variety of gamemodes, from the popular zombie horror PvP to the endless zombie NPC waves.

Unfortunately, I was disappointed soon after it's public release on Steam.  The main menu was hard to navigate through because of the fact that the game starts up in a small window, which doesn't go into fullscreen until you start up a game.  Also, this menu is cluttered with buttons such as the special events going on, your character's inventory, the crafting menu, (etc.)  Some of the major problems that have come up since the release is the broken achievement system and the more recent connectivity issue where no one is able to play the game at all.

There are some minor issues in-game that I'd like to address if and when this game starts working again.  Until then, all I can say is that this game feels VERY incomplete, and that it was rushed before everything was fully tested.  I believe these major issues everyone is having may just be the result of it.  So, don't install this game if you appreciate being rewarded for you shooting skills rather than having to win by having the necessary items that you found by luck or by spending so much time grinding around for drops.

I don't even know where to start. This game does not deserve to be called "Counter Strike" , mainly because when you say Counter Strike , you think of Valve. And when you think of Valve , well , you think of perfection . I will write this review in the most honest way i can and you will see why Nexon is the worst game released this year.

[h1] The game [/h1]

The game is basically just CS 1.6 with its main focus being on Zombie Escape maps. There is nothing special about it , it's just the free version of the original Counter Strike that a poor person with a shitty PC would download. You start the game (after hundreds of tries and connection failures) and you just get confused : [b] TONS , and i mean TONS [/b] of menus and other things that don't do anything in particular. After about 20 seconds you get a pop-up message which tells you to choose a nickname . Unfortunately , even after you put your name and click OK , the message keeps appearing saying to put your name . 30 seconds later another pop-up message saying that the game lost connection will appear. You click OK and the game quits itself to the desktop.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

This piece of junk's gameplay is even worse than its menus. Apparently , the brilliant controls in CS 1.6 were ignored by the devs , so they created their own controls. You will find out that your character shoots with F , changes weapons with left click and many other settings that are not appropriate for a gamer. You will find it hard to move , aim ( sensitivity set to -1 ) , shoot , etc. 

[h1] The game's main focus [/h1]

As the title says , the game focuses on zombies . You have the same generic Zombie Escape modes that you see in EVERY SINGLE Counter Strike . The game also has classic modes , but the main color is gray combined with a dark blue , so you will not see anything , you will not know where to plant the bomb and so on . 
The Zombie Modes are in high number , but they are all the same . Either you're running from the zombies or confronting them face-to-face , you will feel the same . 

[h1] Weapons...? [/h1]

If you hate anime , like I do , you will realise that the weapons look too unrealistic , that they're not designed for humans . They are either too big , or they tend to occupy three quarters of your screen so you cannot see the zeds ( zombies ) coming from your right . The game also includes melee weapons , but again , they're too cyberpunk for my tastes. 

[h1] The maps [/h1]

There are so many shitty maps in this game that you'll start to cry. The game includes a few ugly-as-hell maps that have two main colors : red and black . Pixelated red and black
They are so bad , and you get stuck in so many corners that you will rage quit almost instantly.

[h1] The community [/h1]

The community is either formed of little 12 year olds that think this game is "new" and "next-gen" , or people like me , who are completely confused as to why would Valve add this to their free-to-play section

[h1] The final verdict [/h1]

Overall , this "game" is disgusting . Its gameplay , maps and community (half) are just an offense to Counter Strike . I added an extra point in my final score because i laughed so much with my friends at how bad this garbage is 


 [h1] 2/10 [/h1]

Unfortunately, as much as I wanted to like this game, it just has nothing going for it. I'm fine with the outdated engine; I still play Half-Life 1 as if it was a religion. And even though it‚Äôs free to play, I still won‚Äôt be playing this ever again.

The campaign modes are dull and boring with no strategy whatsoever. You just hold the trigger until everything is dead; maybe throw a grenade every now and then. Because you can buy almost anywhere, it was harder to remember to buy during reloading so that you didn‚Äôt break from shooting, then it was to play the game.

It‚Äôs got the original Counter-Strike 1.6 gameplay, but if you wanted to play that then you‚Äôd be better off playing Counter-Strike 1.6.

The ‚Äòpremier‚Äô feature, the multiplayer zombie hunt mode has been done so many times before, and better. It‚Äôs not hard to find better mods for this kind of gamemode. Heck, I‚Äôve played on Counter-Strike Source servers running server scripts that are better than this.

And finally, it has a rather shallow crafting system that seems utterly pointless considering the base game weapons are perfectly fine. Nothing I crafted had longer than a month until expiry and although the game throws heaps of drops at you, it requires specific combinations that are not explained very well at all.

Personally, I just found this boring. It‚Äôs three game modes hashed together and none of them are that good. You‚Äôve basically got Counter-Strike and Left 4 Dead. If you want to play this, go play those games instead.

WOW...
I was just going to type that, and leave it at that.  Then I realized that's not a reivew, though it would do it justice.  No doubt many people had HIGH hopes for this game.  Myself included, because I have played since CS: 1.1 before STEAM even existed.  Granted, everyone should know that it's not suppose to be completely serious, like CS:GO.  This game is suppose to be it's immature sibling.  So let me go over a few things in the 3-5 minutes I've attempted playing.

- Overall Review.  As much as I want to recommend others play this game, I couldn't suggest it based off what little I've played.  That is, unless you wish to leave constructive criticism.  I whole heartedly believe this game should be shut down, upgraded, reworked, retweaked, and re-released.  The game in it's current state, has zero potential.  Unfortunately.  It may, at best, slightly amuse extremely bored people.  Now, I'm not here to bash the game with intent to be hurtful.  I want to state what I have to say about it, with my honest opinion.

- Graphics Settings.  Couldn't find a graphic setting that felt comfortable, or natural.  I'm rocking a fairly spec'd out PC, that should not have a single issue, x8 the recommended specs at a minimum.  I tried several screen sizes, and nothing really worked for me.  I suppose it could be the old graphics engine throwing me, but i play CS:1.6 just fine.  Perhaps a 27' LED HDMI 1080p Full HD monitor is too big?  It was free, so... ya know.

- The Engine.  Why wasn't the CS:Source Engine used again?  It's still a killer engine, and I'm sure Valve would have agreed to some sort of terms allowing the company to use it.  The physics alone would have been worth it.  But just the simple fact of using an updated engine would do wonders for this game.  Look at Day Of Defeat Source!  That game is still freaking awesome!  I'm aware the game is "Free", but the game is in the risk of ruins dating the graphics so far back.  Dare I say that even using the groundworks for CS:CZ would have greatly improved this game.  All you would have had to do is a bit of tweaking, and recoding.  I mean, that game was built based around bots, and the A.I. skill levels.

- The Mouse Settings.  One of the things I liked the most, are the crosshair types.  That was smooth.  Sure, it's only 4 or 5 types, pixelated, and with an updated engine, the game could impliment several more crosshairs.  HOWEVER, the crosshairs were a failure due to one major pro-tip competitive gamers always have an issue with, the Auto-Adjusting Crosshair (Dynamic Crosshair).  You didn't leave an option to turn that off.  That was a huge quitting point for me.  I understand it's suppose to show the indication of the spread, but I'd rather have my solid crosshairs, watch my spread pattern, burst fire, and adjust my play style accordingly.

- The Music.  Please find a way to auto-off the music once the game/map loads.  I did end up turning the volume down, but realized it annoyed me still, whilst in game.

- The Menu.  Too much clutter.  I've always said at my work, "a clean work area, runs smoother".  Expand the menu.  Space things outs.  Make a direct path for each gamemode, objectives, missions, etc...

- The Console.  The Tilde ~ does work to bring up the console, but the known CS commands like "disconnect" "retry" "quit" were not working for me.  Maybe I was missing something I had to do.  As I said, the time I spend in the game was very little, but enough to make me feel compelled to write a review.

As ALWAYS, check out games for yourself.  I read reviews, but often disregard them, feeling my opinions might be different.  Though i'm usually wrong, I still do things that way.  It's Free, so you have nothing to lose.

A half-life 1 engine game? In 2014? I kind of gathered that there's some sort of retro-fad among indie developers who try to push pixelated graphics, but that is mostly a conscious descision for a certain style. This here looks... well, it would have been cool - 14 years ago. 
Aside from graphics, The game menue is totally overcrowded with submenues, lobbies, crafting areas, awards locations, tech trees and whatnot. You are submitted to a barrage of crafting stuff, consumables, daily missions, weekly missions, ranking, community links and lots of other stuff. And it instantly feels grindy - do 15 daily missions to get these time-limited consumables in order to craft this temporary weapon. Looks like someone had a lot of time to think about all the nice features to create his dream-game (or at least a time-sucking procrastination machine) without actually trying to make the game at least look appealing.

Something nonsensical, yet sometimes fun, i would recommend every mode ( there's quite a lot of them ) except humans vs zombies, because it's all about finding map glitches in maps for humans and rushing those holes and eventually win for zombies, plus annoying commentator voice spam. Rush mode is quite fun, especially with friends or people know how to play it, there's also a default Terrorists vs Counter-Terrorists mode with some enhancements. Tons of new weapons, which are fun to use. You can craft items and weapons similar to tf2, but most of items are temporary and sometimes crafting can fail which is not fun. Playing game is very rewarding, you will get a lot of crafting ingredient drops or even item drops. I would recommend it just for fun factor and don't take it seriously. 

There's some problems to be mentioned, like pre game GUI is 1024x768 only ( for me it's also windowed ), no proper widescreen support. I haven't had any problems with anticheat system or disconnection problems, game never crashed for me. And yeah, this is pretty much CounterStrike : Online with minor diffirences and optimized for everyone, you can't complain.

In its current state, Counter Strike Nexon: Zombies leaves a lot to be desired. 

Servers:
I'm not sure if this is the case for NA players or those outside Europe in general, but playing this game off a stable internet connection in the European servers was not enjoyable whatsoever. Every few seconds (it varied, really) the server would freeze up briefly, leaving me to struggle to do anything and rendering the game virtually unplayable.

Options, UI and general game stability:
Let's start with options first... And we're done. Honestly; all I could see in the Video section of the Options was the ability to change the resolution, screen display mode (which consisted of 'widescreen' and 'regular' - I've no idea what 'regular' is supposed to mean) and the mandatory brightness/gamma. No advanced options whatsoever. 

Under the audio section you have your usual sliders for SFX Volume and Music (Music I'd recommed you turn right down, as not only is it ear-rapey on first start up, it completely overlaps ingame SFX too), Sound Quality settings (High and Low - no medium?) And a few tickboxes for enabling EAX Hardware Support and A3D Hardware Support (I've no idea what these are either). 

As for Mouse and Keyboard, it's your generic Source Engine options set up, with a depressing lack of 'Raw Input' tickboxes. I suppose it makes up for this with the 'Mouse Filter' tickbox, but it's just not the same.. :( Also, it features rebindable keys for all modes in the game, which was nice to see, abeit it being mandatory anyway. The option to invert the mouse it also included.

The 'Multiplayer' section is the most confusing and deceiving section of this Options menu. Reason being that it appears all nice and fine with it's ability to change crosshair (looks, colour, size and whether you want it translucent or not) and spray settings (yeah, custom sprays!) But then throws in a curveball with it's 'Advanced' section. Put simply, it seems like the Developers had no idea where to put spare options and dumped them in there. In this 'Advanced' section you'll see settings for map objects (like the amount of dropped magazines and bodies on the floor), smoke effect quality and volume, as well as UI settings. There is also a bunch of tickboxes for the radar, as well as ones for ingame options (like the UI)

Speaking of which, the UI is awful. Okay, well maybe not THAT awful, but it's still pretty bad. The buy menus are relatively confusing for first-time Counter Strike players and the UI for your weapons and ammo etc are placed in peculiar locations that require the user to look in certain places to see what they've picked up (thus distracting them from that AWP-er lining their sights up on them). This said, there is an option to set the UI to 'classic' which I assume is supposed to be like CS: Source or 1.6, but I personally didn't notice a difference. 

In terms of stability, the game hold up pretty well. The only times I crashed was when trying to close the game, which didn't matter that much. Though I'd like to mention that changing the resolution will force the game into fullscreen unless you tick the box that enables windowed. About the resolution changes too, I had to reboot the game a couple times to actually see the option for 1920x1080, only to realise that it only changes to that resolution when you're in a match, then to default back to windowed when navigating the main menu (why it does that, I don't know). This game is also awfully hard to ALT+TAB out of while in fullscreen, it'll likely take a good couple seconds (maybe more) to minimise, oddly.

Gameplay: 
The gameplay is fairly standard; shoot Terrorists as Counter Terrorists, plant bomb as Terrorists - usual CS basics right there, so I won't be covering the 'Original' game mode (which only consists of 1 map - Dust II). What this game does bring that is completely unique to CS are the 'Zombies' modes. 

The first, and main, mode (called 'Zombie Scenario') is 'meh', to be honest. It'll usually consist of you buying an M249, walking forward, and holding down right mouse, while occasionally interacting with the objects in the environment to further the mission. This game mode also brings it's own 'story' (for lack of better term) in which you play a set amount of these missions in a linear order. I assume the missions vary in type, but I sadly didn't get far enough through the first one without boring myself to death to experience the others. 

The second, lesser important, mode (called 'Zombie Hero') is essentially stock Counter Strike but with the Terrorists playing as the zombies. Sounds cool, huh? Well it is until you realise that, when playing as 'Terrorists', you'll mainly be hiding around corners or chasing the Counter Terrorists in the hopes of getting a kill before you're inevitable demise and wait period until the next round begins. 

Thankfully, the guns in this game do handle like the ones CS Veterans will be familiar with, sticking true to the CS concepts and basics.

Miscellaneous:
Being a free game, there's most likely going to be strings attached, right? Well yes, that's correct, and Counter Strike Nexon: Zombies comes up far from short on that front. Upon opening the game you'll be barraged with rewards of items that are used in an extremely complicated crafting system (I'll talk about this later) as well as friendly info that there's a shop. In this shop you can spend points that I assume you can earn ingame (this isn't specified) and through paying real money. These points are used for buying items that you're only allowed to use for a set period of time before having to rebuy (you have the option to buy it for 10 days or pay extra for 30 days). You can also spend real money on different player models, weapon packages and xp boosts. 

Crafting: 
Mentioned previously, the crafting system is pretty confusing at first, but easy to get the hang of. It works like unboxing, you put in the 'Blueprints' that contain a set amount of items (they're dropped depending on your play time, and come in numbered tiers - the higher number the better), put in the 'Durable' part (this'll decide how long you get to use your crafted item for) and voila! You get the chance to craft some god-tier item or something really rather useless. On a sidenote, the crafting can actually fail, meaning you lose your Blueprint and Part (seriously man, just like unboxing...)

By the way for those who think that there is only zombie modes in this game  there is much much more   and a side note

Not many zombies... not many zombies... let's start off this review with the most riveting sentence ever. Spooky, scary skeletons! Alright, now let me explain. This game has a very old feel to it, and in my opinion, that's good! When I play this game, I can truly say, "I'm playing the original counter strike right now." Wanna know why? Cause It's EXACTLY like the first counter strike! EXACTLY. There are barely any zombies and I sure as hell don't remember any samurai swords. What I'm trying to say is that cs:nz has a special cs:go-ish feel to it in the menu, but in the actual gameplay it has a special cs:s feel to it. I've never seen any zombies or any extremely wierd guns but then again, I've only played it for a couple hours so far. When you shoot someone in this game, your rewarded with an explosion of blood, and whenever you kill someone, you hear a deep, loud voice say "ONE KILL!" And a thing pops up on your screen that says "1 KILL" so when you become a boss at this game and your killing everyone, you will feel proud of yourself. That leads me to my next point as when you first play the game, you instantly become a pro, and I mean INSTANTLY. Ok, maybe not instantly, but after a while. I would highly recommend this game that in all is fun, addicting, distracting, awesome, bloody, amazing and just downright fun.(oh, crap, i already said "fun") It's free and awesome, all ready to go for anyone who has the fortune to stumble apon this game in the steam store. Enjoy killing people on the internet, and have a good day!

It's basically [b]Counter-Strike 1.6[/b] (‚ô•) with slightly improved graphics and gameplay (I really like the crosshair with a dot in the middle) and elements from the famous [i]Zombie Plague[/i] mode, merged with a pay-2-win shop system that [u]really[/u] reminds me of [i]Wolf Team[/i] (and other similar games).  

Yeah, there's a shop system in this game...

...but I'm not going to be a whiny bit·¥Ñh about it (check most of the non-recommended reviews), because I'm not forced to spend money on this, since I can just play on regular 1.6-style servers with all the original characters and weapons. 

A thing that did annoy me about this game is the removal of tons of console commands and the ability to have an own user config (the famous "autoexec.cfg") is gone, but I think this can be added in future updates.

--- [b]Edit[/b] ---
I'd like to add that I'm not mad at the shop system: weapons can be crafted so easily without spending real life money (there's even a chance of getting permanent items) and the only "pay2win" aspect of the game are some crappy female skins with irritating death sounds that you can quickly frag. Yes, there's people who waste money on that (well, Nexon has to make some profit somehow).

In its current state, Counter Strike Nexon: Zombies leaves a lot to be desired. 

Servers:
I'm not sure if this is the case for NA players or those outside Europe in general, but playing this game off a stable internet connection in the European servers was not enjoyable whatsoever. Every few seconds (it varied, really) the server would freeze up briefly, leaving me to struggle to do anything and rendering the game virtually unplayable.

Options, UI and general game stability:
Let's start with options first... And we're done. Honestly; all I could see in the Video section of the Options was the ability to change the resolution, screen display mode (which consisted of 'widescreen' and 'regular' - I've no idea what 'regular' is supposed to mean) and the mandatory brightness/gamma. No advanced options whatsoever. 

Under the audio section you have your usual sliders for SFX Volume and Music (Music I'd recommed you turn right down, as not only is it ear-rapey on first start up, it completely overlaps ingame SFX too), Sound Quality settings (High and Low - no medium?) And a few tickboxes for enabling EAX Hardware Support and A3D Hardware Support (I've no idea what these are either). 

As for Mouse and Keyboard, it's your generic Source Engine options set up, with a depressing lack of 'Raw Input' tickboxes. I suppose it makes up for this with the 'Mouse Filter' tickbox, but it's just not the same.. :( Also, it features rebindable keys for all modes in the game, which was nice to see, abeit it being mandatory anyway. The option to invert the mouse it also included.

The 'Multiplayer' section is the most confusing and deceiving section of this Options menu. Reason being that it appears all nice and fine with it's ability to change crosshair (looks, colour, size and whether you want it translucent or not) and spray settings (yeah, custom sprays!) But then throws in a curveball with it's 'Advanced' section. Put simply, it seems like the Developers had no idea where to put spare options and dumped them in there. In this 'Advanced' section you'll see settings for map objects (like the amount of dropped magazines and bodies on the floor), smoke effect quality and volume, as well as UI settings. There is also a bunch of tickboxes for the radar, as well as ones for ingame options (like the UI)

Speaking of which, the UI is awful. Okay, well maybe not THAT awful, but it's still pretty bad. The buy menus are relatively confusing for first-time Counter Strike players and the UI for your weapons and ammo etc are placed in peculiar locations that require the user to look in certain places to see what they've picked up (thus distracting them from that AWP-er lining their sights up on them). This said, there is an option to set the UI to 'classic' which I assume is supposed to be like CS: Source or 1.6, but I personally didn't notice a difference. 

In terms of stability, the game hold up pretty well. The only times I crashed was when trying to close the game, which didn't matter that much. Though I'd like to mention that changing the resolution will force the game into fullscreen unless you tick the box that enables windowed. About the resolution changes too, I had to reboot the game a couple times to actually see the option for 1920x1080, only to realise that it only changes to that resolution when you're in a match, then to default back to windowed when navigating the main menu (why it does that, I don't know). This game is also awfully hard to ALT+TAB out of while in fullscreen, it'll likely take a good couple seconds (maybe more) to minimise, oddly. 

Gameplay: 
The gameplay is fairly standard; shoot Terrorists as Counter Terrorists, plant bomb as Terrorists - usual CS basics right there, so I won't be covering the 'Original' game mode (which only consists of 1 map - Dust II). What this game does bring that is completely unique to CS are the 'Zombies' modes. 

The first, and main, mode (called 'Zombie Scenario') is 'meh', to be honest. It'll usually consist of you buying an M249, walking forward, and holding down right mouse, while occasionally interacting with the objects in the environment to further the mission. This game mode also brings it's own 'story' (for lack of better term) in which you play a set amount of these missions in a linear order. I assume the missions vary in type, but I sadly didn't get far enough through the first one without boring myself to death to experience the others. 

The second, lesser important, mode (called 'Zombie Hero') is essentially stock Counter Strike but with the Terrorists playing as the zombies. Sounds cool, huh? Well it is until you realise that, when playing as 'Terrorists', you'll mainly be hiding around corners or chasing the Counter Terrorists in the hopes of getting a kill before you're inevitable demise and wait period until the next round begins. 

Thankfully, the guns in this game do handle like the ones CS Veterans will be familiar with, sticking true to the CS concepts and basics.

Miscellaneous:
Being a free game, there's most likely going to be strings attached, right? Well yes, that's correct, and Counter Strike Nexon: Zombies comes up far from short on that front. Upon opening the game you'll be barraged with rewards of items that are used in an extremely complicated crafting system (I'll talk about this later) as well as friendly info that there's a shop. In this shop you can spend points that I assume you can earn ingame (this isn't specified) and through paying real money. These points are used for buying items that you're only allowed to use for a set period of time before having to rebuy (you have the option to buy it for 10 days or pay extra for 30 days). You can also spend real money on different player models, weapon packages and xp boosts. 

Crafting: 
Mentioned previously, the crafting system is pretty confusing at first, but easy to get the hang of. It works like unboxing, you put in the 'Blueprints' that contain a set amount of items (they're dropped depending on your play time, and come in numbered tiers - the higher number the better), put in the 'Durable' part (this'll decide how long you get to use your crafted item for) and voila! You get the chance to craft some god-tier item or something really rather useless. On a sidenote, the crafting can actually fail, meaning you lose your Blueprint and Part (seriously man, just like unboxing...) 

To conclude this lengthy review (and give those too lazy a brief TL;DR), I wouldn't recommend Counter Strike Nexon: Zombies until the Developers can add incentives to make waiting for the download to finish worth it. Though, if you have the internet to download it quickly, go ahead and give it a try. Who knows? You might find enjoyment out of it.

It's a mystery to me how professional gamedesigners don't realise that the whole Zombies vs Humans gamemode is pretty flawed because
1. Any player with a brain will find that one spot on the map where the zombies won't reach them making it a boring camping game for the humans and a boring dull Charge-and-get-killed type of gameplay for the zombies
2. Because the players are smart enough to hide at the one spot zombies have a hard time getting there especially because they can bodyblock eachother, let's use the spot on the roof on italy for example, you have to do a little bit of jump and run to get on top of there and I keep getting pushed off by my teammates because they cant wait, and even if they would wait, I'd get shot by the players in about 2 secons. Now if all the zombies could jump up there at the same time it would be a different story but I think bullets penetrate in this game too so nevermind.

This could be improved by giving the zombies some sort of grenade per spawn but I didn't see anything similiar while playing.

Zombies.

Everyone loves zombies, which is why truely inspirational, spiritual journeys such as Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies exist. 

With mind bogglingly strong boxes you'll be holding down left mouse click for hours at a time, you might think this is a 'boring' or 'mundane' concept HOWEVER with the literal piles of zombies swarming you constantly said mechanic becomes truely delightful.

Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies also has majestic boss battles with original mechanics like 'constantly insta-killing you and knocking your weapon out of your hands' mechanics like these show that the video game franchise as a whole as grown and ascended past it's 8-BIT era.

This game...
Imagine if you will, beating your head against the wall, over and over and over. And then you mostly have the contents of this game.

Based off CS 1.6 this game forces you to kill boxes, with many thousands of hitpoints, 15,000-30,000, and this was pretty unbearable, but then imagine that the makers decided that having the amount of damage dealt to these boxes scales down with the amount of people in the game. When you eventually get to a "boss" it is simply one of the aforementioned boxes that does an insignificant amount of damage per attack, but suddenly will use it instant kill move. To give perspective, it can use this move with no consequence, no warning, and no escape, even right as you respawn it can do it. 

The makers of this game clearly thought that harder difficulty=higher amount of enemy health, and even on easy difficulty this game is a rediculous waste of time, that will bore you to pieces while you shoot boxes blocking the path.

Alright look. There are a lot of bad reviews about this game but im going to give you an honest good one.

This game is free, and for a free game it's pretty damn good. The graphics are the old 1.6 but the gameplay is amazing. The community is yet to show me a bad side and all the guns are pretty even. Everything in the cash shop can just be earned through playing the game, the cash shop is just a quicker way of getting it. The game rewards the players who work for their guns. You can level up and get better as you play. If you want a free counter strike, it doesnt get better than this. and if you want a bit of a nostalgic feeling of the old counter strike, this will remind you. You can listen to the reviews complaining about "Paying for guns" and just putting a bad rep on nexon and all the sort. But the truth is, you get what you get. It's a free game and all free games have their ups and downs. And this one definetly has more ups than downs. It's worth the download.  People also need to remember, this game just came out. It still has plenty of room for updates and the like. Who knows, a ton of stuff could be changed in the future. Most of the haters are probably just call of duty players that wanted something like a free COD. but if you're a hardcore Counter Strike player, or even someone new to it, this is a great learning curve, and experience. I ask you, Give this a try.

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, "If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28, I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

(Wonder why I give it a positive rating? Read the whole review.)
This game pisses me off.
It's almost a pay to win game, I say almost because you can still obtain the rarer guns just by logging in and completing some missions. However, the "Points" system still hinders you to where you need to grind like a motherfu*ker to get the sufficant points to GET A CHANCE to get the "good guns". With the crafting system comes weapons that do nothing and weapons that are literally a godsend, even if you have a godgun, it runs on a temporary system, meaning YOU HAVE LIMITED DAYS TO USE THE GUN. Yes there are 72 day-Pernament materials but it's very rare to get OR you can pay for it. 
Another thing that pisses me off is how SLOW it takes to level up. I almost clocked in a day AND i played the OBeta and i'm a level 7. Sure there are EXP Cupons and EXP Boost weekends, but the time it takes to reach these levels are horrendus, especually when you get a crate that you can't open because of your low level. 
To add to the hard time it takes to rank up, you can be disconected from the current server your playing on! Even if you have a good connection, it's still possible that you can be disconnected, and once you do, YOU DO NOT GET XP AND LOOT DROPS. It's punishing when you play for a good hour on a zombie senario mission to get some points to craft a weapon you want, and you disconnect randomly for no reason, RIGHT BEFORE THE BOSS DIES. This happened to me more than 10 times now. I've checked my ping, and it was locked at around 30. 
Another thing that just urkes my shit is when I'm playing zombie hero type modes, and it takes forever to kill the enemy zombies. I understand if the first few zombies need 7000 HP, so they can infect others, however, this becomes an issue because most of the guns can't match the Zombies HP, meaning most of the LMG's and like 1 assault rifle is useful! Pistols, shotguns, and sniper rifles are almost useless, I say almost because guns do slow enemies, some even knock back so it can buy you time. ANOTHER thing that gets annoying is the announcer voice in Zombie Hero mode, it says "The Zombies Will Be Back" EVERY TIME SOMEONE DIES, which means YOU HEAR THAT MOTHERFUCKA 32 TIMES MAX. 

However...

I still keep coming back.
Why, you may ask?
Well, even with all of these issues, i'm still hooked. It reminded me of the good ol' times on consoles with private matches on CoD and some servers on CS:S. The gameplay is addicting, you want to survive and fight the hoards of enemies with your friends, and finish the fight with a raid boss. You want badass weapons that your friends have, so you keep fighting the issues to obtain the items needed to craft the weapon. There are enchantments to make your guns and even your zombie character (ZH Mode) even better. There are different species of zombies, and each come with different abilities. You can join a "family" (A clan, basically) and interact with them and play with them. There are ranked modes, and you have a sperate rank in seperate modes, so you can brag who's better according to ranks. And finally, the game comes with a free CS 1.6. Yeah, a free CS 1.6.

Honestly, I can only complain but in the end it's your choice to try it out or not. I'm giving it a positive rating because first of all, it's free to play, and second, I want you to experience the game itself, and from there you can say if the game blows or not. Much like movie critics, someone can say it sucks, and they maybe right, but who knows if you like it until you watch it.

This game isn't perfect, but still worth a shot.

At first glance this may seem like a free version of Counter-Strike: Source, and at a closer glance may seem like Counter-Strike meets Left 4 Dead, but this game is far more complex than that.

For starters, this game [i]is[/i] based on CS:S, and essencially still plays like traditional CS, with terrorists and counter-terrorists. It's the addition of the zombies that makes all the different forms of play so unique.

For those who just want to play CS without having to worry about the zombies, the Original mode is just that: Counter-Strike. Even has good old de_dust2.

The Zombie Scenario mode plays similar to Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2, where there is one team, either terrorists or counter-terrorists, and another team of computer-controlled zombies. You reach the end and fight a boss. Simple. 

Oh yeah, and there are obstacles you have to shoot down with your guns. They have a lot of HP. You'll find yourself running back to the restocking area to get more ammo a lot.

As you complete the mission and kill zombies, a bar on the bottom of the screen fills up. When it is completely filled, you level up, giving you more HP and more ammo. Keep in mind, this level up system is exclusive to this mode and is separate from your global level.

The Zombie Hero mode plays similar to Left 4 Dead Versus. One team is the humans, the other team is the zombies. You can choose to be either humans or zombies.

Most of the items you can get just by playing or crafting. Sure, there is a store, but the items for the most part do not require real world money. You purchase some items, such as new characters, [i]with[/i] real-world money, yes, but most items are purchased with points.

And you also get these points by playing. Playing X time gives you Y points, playing X more time gives you Z points. Simple.

There are also missions you can choose to complete every day and every week. Beating one of these missions gives you a reward: either a random gun or random crafting materials, your choice.

Overall, this game piqued my interest when I found it a few weeks ago, probably before it started coming into beta. I dare say that this may be one of the best F2P games on Steam.

This is terrible. Shop is over priced ($9.99 for pornish Soldier or pornish reporter!), performance is bad, menus are unusable.  Hits cause screen flash with no indication of direction.   This is half done and terrible.  

Don't waste your time and just play any Valve CS game, even 1.6.  I don't think this game would have been good even back in 1998, which is where it looks to have stolen its art and art direction from.

The game itself consists of several modes. All are mods that can be found on every version of counterstrike.

The only difference is that in this game you get to craft different weapons. And here's the kicker, you don't keep them. Yeah, you read that right.

Every gun you craft has a time limit of X amount of days based on what you used to craft it. After that it disappears from your inventory forever.

Those cool items you get for participating in events the devs throw? Gone in 15 days. That awesome gun you crafted? Gone in 1 day to 2 months. 

But hey, at least you can buy crafting items in the shop for real money. 

The actual gameplay is literally just stolen ideas from the mods people use in the real counterstrike game. Apart from the "story mode" where you literally just survive for 2 and a half minutes until the next wave. Repeat for 20 rounds, takes about a half hour. But if you want those cool event items that are going to disappear in two weeks then you have to do this on at least 10 maps. That's right, 20 rounds, a half hour each if you don't fail at all, on ten maps. That's assuming  the game isn't dead and there are actually people to play with, otherwise good luck.


Game is the definition of a scam, do not pay anything. Just go play the actual counterstrike mods. They're ten times better anyways.

As someone with a lot of Experience playing Nexon games, who spent one year in Maplestory, five years and over two grand in Mabinogi, several years and over fifteen-hundred dollars in Combat Arms, and beta-tested Vindictus before finally calling it quits with this company, I'd say this game may captivate your attention at first but it will swiftly get boring, unless you start shoveling money into it. Once you start pushing money into their games they are only fun as long as you keep throwing money at it. They are all severely pay-to-win and take heavy advantage of a mechanic like micro-transactions with virtual currency. 

CS Nexon: Zombies at first glance reminded me of zombie mod in Combat Arms just repackaged with the Counter Strike brand. I've only downloaded it to give out a warning that Nexon is immorally taking advantage of using addictive personalities to shovel money into their games. Don't spend a dime or you may be pulled into their trap, however, this game will lose its luster very swiftly. 

Thank you. -Barri

A poor man's version of a very poorly booted mod on 1.6
I much rather prefer playing the left 4 dead 2 mod on CS 1.6 than recommend this game.  The L4D2 mod on 1.6 offers more diversity in terms of human abilities as well as the zombies (multiple classes for each with their own special abilities).
Still suffers the same problems as the other games, where victory on the human side is so incredibly difficult to obtain that exploiting is almost required for a victory (aka going off the map).

Just quick being cheap and buy Counter-Strike 1.6 and get more diversity in game play mods as well as better gameplay overall...

Played 25 mins of it.

Joined a random zombie game. Was boring as hell.

In this zombie match, me and various ( about 9 other ) Counter Terrorists were constantly attacked by zombies and had to keep moving through streets. It sounds fun, but is awful. VERY awful.

For the whole experience, I had about 7 machine guns blazing in my ear as well as "Fire in the hole" going off every 2 seconds.

The gameplay was bad too. What happened was, we had to move through streets. But, every 20-30 seconds, we had to stop and clear a barricade. These barricades had about 30,000 health each. What you had to do was get about 8 people shooting down the barricade and the other 2 people shooting zombies.

The zombies were really easy to kill. They had low HP, and each time they attacked they dealt 1-2 damage to you. What's worse, is every few zombie kills, you would get a level. These levels seemed to increase your max HP pool by about 5 per level. While it sounds reasonable, it was easy. For the first 10 levels, it took 1 zombie kill per level. And so before you know it, at level 35ish I had 380 or so health and was practically unkillable. I'm not sure if it was just me, but health seemed to regenerate. And fast.

So for the whole experience, it was easy and boring. You shoot at walls 75% of the time and after each match, you become partially deaf for an hour unless you play without sound.

I understand I only played one gamemode, but I really couldn't be bothered playing more, and thought I might as well just share my experience here in review form.

This game is no better than the cheezy zombie mods freely available on 1.6 & CSS servers. Save your hard drive space and don't bother downloading this game.  There is absolutely no balancing in this game, I played on a Dust map and it's impossible to win as humans. The zombies have extremely high HP and respawn. One stab and you're a zombie just like the free mods but with even worse balancing.

This company is only out to make a quick buck out of you with microstransactions. Don't fall for it.

BASE GAMEMODE REVIEW (non zombie stuff)
I'd say 2 hours is more than enough to say this: Don't waste the bandwidth. I've asked many people why they were appealed to install this and they all said "Because its free." Although thats a plus I have seen little more reasons to play this other than about two more. Those being the level systems and the neat guns it has when you have the ability to craft them. But like almost every other F2P model out there, they are limited access and most have advantages over the stock items. The game is pretty much Combat Arms (another of nexons f2p titles plauged with microtransactions) and 1.6 reskinned.

Zombie stuff
The zombie mode plays similar to the zombie run gamemodes on source games, its fun with friends and to pass time, but the maps are boring after a while. The mode does offer some variations of zombies but that is affected by the F2P microtransaction system too.

This game. Let me start off by saying I have never reviewed a game before but feel I should in this case.  I was suspicious as soon as I read all the negative reviews but thought hey I'll give it a shot. I like CS, I like Zombies, I should like this too. What this game boils down to after playing a couple matches it bascally this. Spawn in with the Negev (or equivalent machine gun), completely ignore all other weapons and I mean ALL, SMGs, Shotguns, other pistols, useless. Then proceed to midlessly hold left left click and sway the mouse from side to side. Solved. Either that or get completely overun by the insane amounts of idential zombies. Thats it. It is a very boring, repeditive game and thats all is all. I fell that maybe if this game has more modern elements (graphics, gore system, decent models etc) this game could be more fun but as is the game runs off a decade old system (CS:CZ) and it really shows. I know its free and all but it seriouslly doesn't even warrent the Download space to get it.

TL;DR Not a big download and its free but it really isnt worth your time.

*** EDIT ***

I am well aware I have over 150 hours on record (blame other games being on patch day).
My stance on the game has still not changed, but I'm in a much calmer place, at the time being, so I'll try giving it a less... ragey... review.

-MINUSES-
-The game is still very much p2w, as the best guns in the game are invariably purchasable for real money, or obtainable through the Death Star Torpedo shot that is the Decoder.

-The censorship is still there, and is just as noticable to those that can understand what they're saying, which I will get to later. The chat is annoyingly filled with astrixes, even for stupid phrases that only an over-protective mum or Chinese game would want or need.

-You still can't have a PROPER server, nor go to ANY server that isn't (in the scheme of things) run by Nexon. Seriously, I challenge you to find a PLAYER OR COMMUNITY HOSTED server. This has led to it being as though you were playing with bots, even with a full room.

-You cannot change your name without forking over a few bucks, you know, as if this were some sort of MMO. This also applies to clan tags (or tites, as they've been turned into).

-You will find the same exact 3-5 maps being repeated over, and over, and over.

-There's no way to filter languarges. This is especially problematic if you don't fluently speak Spanish in the American regional servers.

-Different player models have different stats, AGAIN giving an advantage to those wiling to fork money over (or who win the lottery-level luck of the Decoder).

-The twice-afore-mentioned Decoder CONSTANTLY plays the 'so-and-so player you have probobly no damned clue who is has just won <INSERT OVERPOWERED WEAPON / PLAYER MODEL HERE> message, which constantly interrupts the few times when someone manages to /actually/ start up a dialogue.

+PLUSSES+

+It's good to fill in the nostalgia, for a few hours.

+It provides the oppertunity to therapeutically punch zombies.

+It's a good time waster, when everything else you play is patching.

=That... really is all I can think about. Sorry guys. In the end, I wouldn't recommend this game, and I'm sorry about the saltiness in the O.P.

Counter-Strike: Nexon Zombies is a strange one.

The game was first "Remade" from Condition Zero to the Korean gaming market under the title "Counter-Strike: Online", then it was backported to the western market as Counter-Strike: Nexon Zombies with multiple new gamemodes including the titular zombie fuzz.

So yeah, the game runs on the old GoldSrc engine which does admittedly look a bit cryptic by today's standards, but then again, that never stopped people from playing CS1.6 since it's still a popular title even after all these years and modern iterations of the series.

The game features 20 different game modes, new weapons and a whole bunch of new content including levels and crafting system. Everything that was in 1.6 is here as well, and more. So why are people hating it? Well, the presentation might be one thing, from the main menu to the game itself, it looks honestly pretty bad and unwelcoming. If i was a developer i'd try to fix that as soon as possible, since there is really not all that much wrong with the game itself.

Open Beta didn't have too much stuff in the in-game market so i cant really comment on the "P2W" factor people are referring to, but it doesn't honestly look too bad. I've seen much worse even on western games that i wont name here.

So, would i recommend you to play this game?

It depends, if you enjoyed playing CS1.6 back in the day like i did, then you'll probably find this a nostalgic trip that you'll most likely enjoy quite a bit. If you didn't, well, i guess you should give it a try regardless since it's free. Just dont be surprised if you find it a bit underwhelming on the graphics standpoint.

Old score for CSN:Z: 7.75
New score: 8.25

[b]Post-Beta Review (10/10/2014):[/b]
So after some more gameplay and experimenting with CSN:Z, I can proudly conclude that I would still recommend this game. After learning how to properly use crafted weapons and playing a couple new gamemodes, it made the game feel more complete and playable. Not too much has been changed from the beta, but there are minor tweaks, like the main menu going into windowed mode, which is kinda quirky, but works.

The gameplay still feels solid. The only times I felt cheated were when I was surrounded by zombies and there was nothing I could do. As I've stated in my old review, there are a plethora of different modes to play from, from the original Counter-Strike, to an Infection-like gamemode (which I covered earlier), to my favorite modes, the Scenarios. Zombie Scenarios pit you against a horde of zombies, and you have to destroy structures while staying alive. Human Scenarios throw you into an arena-like area, and there's a helicopter circling around, dropping troops on top of you. It can get pretty intense at times.

I can say that crafting is still pretty solid. I know a bit more about it than I did in the beta, and it's a very simple, yet interesting system. I hope I can experiment more once I get better items.

Overall, I still think CSN:Z is still a decent game. I would recommend you to give it a try. It is free, so there shouldn't be any harm, right?

My final score for this game is an 8.25/10.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[b]OLD REVIEW (9/25/2014):[/b]

Although Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies has its quirks, it has some very enjoyable gamemodes, and an interesting crafting system as well. Due to the short time of the beta, I won't be able to review everything the game has to offer.

One of the most interesting gamemodes I saw was Zombie Scenario. Think of a Minecraft/Rust/7 Days to Die esque scenario where you have time in the day to gather resources and build a defense, but at night, hordes of Zombies try to attack your base. I really want to see how this mode will play out in the future.

There were other cool modes as well, such as Zombie Hero, which is the equivalent to Halo or CoD's Infection modes. You can also play the original CS modes as well, making this a free version of Counter-Strike.

The crafting system was fairly interesting as well. Instead of renting weapons *glares at Warface*, you obtain Graded Blueprints and Durables throughout gameplay. Blueprints are used in the creation of weapons. Durables determine how long you will have that weapon, sort of like it's durability, hence the name. There are 1 day durables, 3 day, 7 day, 24-30 day, and I even managed to have a 72-90 day! The blueprints are also ranked too, Grade 1, 2, 3, and so on. You can also combine Durables or Blueprints together to make higher quality items.

Unfortunately, there are a few issues with this game. The performance, for one, can be insanely low at times, due to how much gunfire and entities are active, making the game harder to play. I never experienced getting disconnected from the servers, however, like other people have reported.

Another issue is the bosses. These guys are f**king bullet sponges. Sure, I get the mission is to kill the boss, but is it necessary to take 25+ minutes to do so?

As I said before, this game has it's quirks, but overall? It's not a bad game. It has solid gameplay, and could keep you busy for quite some time.

My final rating for this game is a 7.75/10.

It reminds me of a mix between Gunz 2 itemization(<<I dislike this), and Left 4 Dead. With some counter-strike like maps and game modes. I wont lie I always have and always will dislike the idea of hourly or daily limited items. Gameplay of survival game mode I thought was unique because it got harder as the round progressed, and as the rounds progressed. Crafting I am sort of neutral on it depends on how it is setup. It mostly depends on if its going to be open market through steam. If it is going to consist meerly on how it is setup right now I dont like it. Graphics for a beta for what the game describes it to be, it is what it is a Free 2 play, with original counter strike play and feel.

Basically I think there are many things they can expand upon, and I think they are on a good start. I think if they progress the customization, the crafting, and have a open market through steam market. This game could become a good base for a mmofps. Maybe have a Item/skin involvement with CS-GO.

I am recommending this game not for what it is right now, but what I think it could turn into.

2021 NOTE:
As this for some reason became my most viewed review, i'd like to point out couple of things:
 - This review was made during beta of the game in 2014 and i have not played it since. Probably a lot has changed since then so i'd recommend checking more recent reviews.
- My english was far worse back then, so excuse my past self's bad english.
Aaaaaand, here's my original 2014 beta review:

If anyone ever played Zombie mode in any CS, they know what this is. In the game all players are humans. After few seconds one of you becomes Zombie. One hit = Become Zombie. Humans have to survive for few minutes and Zombies have to turn all humans into zombies. The game is acceptable as a Human, but as a Zombie you will have hard times. If group of humans shoots at you, there is nothing you can do - you can barely move, you cant shoot (maybe you can with different zombies but i was not able to do so) Unfortunately, most players feels to be heroic and just run around in open area. There are also alternative gamemodes for this, for example when one of humans becomes a "Hero" with special gun.

Other gamemode is zombie survival (or how its called), which sounds nice, but is actually pretty bad. All players play for half hour in same small area. Every wave many zombies spawn everywhere... and you literraly have to keep turning around to kill everything thats coming your way. If someone was spectating, they would think that you are dancing.

Zombie Scenario... or something like that... there are randomly chosen few random zombies to chase humans. They have to follow the signs and run. Sometimes they have to press something or shoot something. As a zombie you actually have to do the same... but instead of trying to escape - youre trying to hit them and turn them into zombies. I had slightly more fun playing this gamemode.

The highlight of this game is Zombie Shelter mode. You have shelter and you have to protect it. During day you have to gather resources around the map, look for black market to buy a weapons. During night there will be horde of zombies trying to destroy your shelter. With resources you can build turrets, walls and other buildings. To win, you have to kill two bosses.

There is lot of alternative gamemodes to these and there is also a "Original" and "Basic" gamemode. Thats just classic CS 1.6 with small changes.

Main Menu feels very uncomfortable. Craft menu contains pointless PIN code screen. If you try to end the game, game will try to convince you to keep playing with "You havent finished your Special mission" or "You did not accepted your daily reward"... Even leaving the game before the end of match will result in loosing 100 points. I have no idea what are those points for.

+ Lot of gamemodes
+ Shelter Mode
+ New weapons
+ Players of older Zombie mods will love this

- Gameplay as Zombie
- Main Menu
- Some booring gamemodes

5/10

A bizarre, horrifying nightmare of nostalgia.

The worst thing is that some people think this is made by #ValveOfficial

There are so many things wrong with this game that don't make sense, it introduces problems never seen in CS 1.x to give you a demented experience that's a shadow of the game it blatantly rips off... and it has microtransactions. YES, CS with Micro-transactions

It always needs to run elevated, the first Steam game I've seen to do so, probably because it uses an exotic anti-cheat system that no one's heard of.
If you choose a name that's taken you'll get a connection terminated error that forces you to quit to the desktop. 
Because of this, I now have "Steam" has a nickname, there's no availability check and like other gimmicky F2P titles you need to pay to change your name... probably, I don't really know or care. "Steam" is a perfectly okay name with me for a game I'll never play.
The interface is locked to 1024x768, regardless of your specified in-game resolution. This doesn't sound like a big deal, but it is.
The console doesn't accept most commonly used GoldSrc commands, and looks like some horrid half-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• bespoke job that was never meant to be used.
North America and Oceania are considered the same region for the purposes of matchmaking.
250ms is considered "Ideal" ping.
I don't know if there are dedicated servers, but the game I just played had it's hoster switch and everyone dropped out. So, yeah, P2P CS.

Some of what I've just mentioned may be inaccurate, but whatever, I'm still giving this review more effort than the people who rolled out this rubbish.

I am  normally VERY LIENIENT when it  comes to  giving a game a fair shake..not this time.

This  is inexcusable. I'll admit  I  like  Counter strike  as I  have been  playing it since it's first iterations as a  modification for Half Life, and I  will  openly and  honestly admit with  no shame that it is  not for everyone and  the hardcore crowd is  kind of niche. and in some circles almost "cultish" in it's following.

So we  know it's not  "sacred" , just a well made mod that  grew organically into a  long standing well made  game series with  some  "spotty"  moments on it's reputation..it was NEVER  perfect but..

With  all of this  said...THIS unspeakable  piece of crap is  how Nexon  chooses to  handle the C.S. series  built upon the backbone of the  most revered version of  counter strike we have what can  only be described as a cancerous growth ... a  tumor  both  hideous to behold as it is  devistating to  it's host.

Poor choices of modes,  poor Implementation  , no optimization  truncated menus and descriptions in said menus prove that Nexon  truly  does not care for the  consumer/playerbase.  Tacked on  thoughtless poorly balanced playmodes , patheticly coded poor  bots, unimaginative  zombie designs and gameplay better executed in  almost ANY  amatuer  mod of ill repute let alone one  that was crafted with  the skill and love that early  Counter Strike  mod revisions were.

6-7 flavors  of crappy  couldn't be @$$ed to  care "zombie" / infected modes, a  money grubbing cash  greedy  "rent-2-PWN" gun/gear shop crafting system  designed by a  five year old huffing glue, a few  cheap "extreme"  font /U.I. changes that only make the whole experience come off as  cheaper than it really  ever was ( and note this is a "FREE to play" game so  cheaper than that is  pretty  deplorable.)  the best  maps in the game are the ones  that came from 1.6. but even they  didn't escape  being mangled  by fog and other pointless effects .

This is how Nexon treats a  well known staple of the E-sports scene and  much  liked  cornerstone of the FPS genre a classic..they  slash burn rip tear  mangle  and bloat the body  by exposing it  to only  Cthuhlu -knows-what.

and this unspeakably  mangled unholy mess of a shambling creature wearing  a tattered skin of the   classic  Counter Strike is  what they  have been  pushing off  onto China and South Korea...

I apologize China, South korea from the  bottom of my and many more  gamer's hearts, these sociopaths gave you a  poisoned pill  with a candy coating, they decived you and they  decived the ones who  saldy  lent them the rights to  license the Counter Strike series to your markets.

THIS is what is  killing  C.S. , this is what is killing gaming in  wide open markets that  are not  the US,Canada E.U. Japan Australia and  the other  "entrenched" markets.

and the real kick to the  junk  not all  foreign markets got   this  HORRIBLE   wannabe  CS 1.6 with  mods..Japan actually got a GOOD Altered version of Counter Strike : Source called CS: NEO put out by Namco of all companies in  2005... 

Take a moment and let that sink in..2005  Namco had  one year to take  CS :Source which  was not as ballanced at the  time as even C.S. 1.3. they did more  justice to this series almost 10 years ago to the the moment I  wrote this review than  Nexon  did  since  getting their  hands on  the license in  2008 with  tech  that's almot 14 years of  work careful work ballancing out  1.6 to  be what it is  ..still one of the most  wonderfully ballanced FPS titles to ever exist. 

It was never the best looking but it was one of the most studied, balanced and playable FPS  titles to this very day , and as of me writing this   a  pillar of  the  E-sports community  for it's execution.

All of that  hard work , all of that progress  was FORCEFULLY and willingly broken or  just  trown to the wayside like detritus by Nexon for a profit and it all culinated in this diasterpice  .

I  have  played CS:NEO it's  actually  unmistakably  , unabashedly a good game it's just a region specific reskinned and visually altered  "vanilla" CS : Source  with a  few minor add ons.

I would gladly  pay for that game even  with that with a  monetized gear / guns system hands  down over this with every last bit of pay pay content permanently  unlocked.
 I  would  still  gladly take CS:NEO  over this  mess even if  Nexon  paid me fairly to play this chunk of  awful intentions made manifest. 

This is not a game...this is a  mugging over TCPIP.

This is a blatent  cash grab using a well known name drop. this is  an affront and an insult to gamers EVERYWHERE.

If you want to play Counter-Strike with Zombies try out the Zombie Mod and/or Zombie Escape servers on Counter-Strike 1.6, Counter-Strike: Source, or Counter-Strike: Global Offensive.  All of these blow Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies out of the water.  The difference in quality and fun is day and night.

Seriously Valve?  I can't even comprehend what I just played.  How could you let a third-party defile Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Zombie Mod so thoroughly?  I'm serious, this is very concerning.

First off, This was originally a Korean Collab with Nexon and Steam so that people from Korea or Japan can have a taste of the greatness that is Counter-Strike. Now that we got that out of the way, let's get into the meat of the game - The Horde Mode.

1 team is the Survivors aka the Counter Terrorists while the other teams are the zombies. If you are thinking "Alliance of Valiant Arms" then yeah, it is a rehash of AvA's Zombie mode. Hell, Nexon used to have AvA!

Anyway, people can buy shit like Grenades, Hammers, that kind of thing OR they can throw over some cash to become an animu girl that's wearing little to nothing but pants and a black bra. Because Waifu Material.
Also, she can use a Triple Barrel Shotgun and double infinity pistols. Awesome.

Like all of the other reviews, this game has ALOT of bugs. It's a goddamn hybrid of AvA, L4D2, and CS 1.6, I am not going to get into the bugs of it because it would be kicking a dead horse (Connection Issues, Overlay, P2P*, etc)

Overall, this is just a Joke/Animu version of Counter Strike 1.6 from the Twisted minds of Nexon. And despite all of the fuck ups that this game has, i can still get a few laughs and fun times with this game. Get this game if you want to have something to laugh at while playing Counter Strike at the same time.**

Made in 2008 and Released on Steam in 2014, It's [strike] Counter Strike for Korea: Zombie Waifu Edition [/strike] Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies!
*This was ALSO in AvA, DFO, and Maplestory. Nexon sure loves it's P2P shops don't they?
**Seriously, It's halarious seeing a guy running away from another guy with a gigantic hammer.

I think i am giving this game more effort with this review than the game developers gave it when making it. 
The resolotion is constantly stuck on 1280x1024 and cannot be increased past this.
The Server groups are North America and Oceania (One Server with ping of 250 seen as normal), Russia (CIS) Yeah they have a server for the former USSR but not for asia as general, and then europe (Russia not in Europe but Australia in NA?)
When i read Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies, i would have expected you know them to use the engine of counterstrike global offensive, or atleast Source because its 2014? How can they even justify using the old engine of CS 1.6 when they have a partnership with Valve?
The gameplay is laggy and dry, half the games do not even run on any sort of zombie mode and overall this game seems like an effortless pile put together by an unskilled modder.

Overall this game is a waste of the bandwith it takes to download it, anyone thinking about playing this for zombies is better off just playing zombie mod servers on CSS or CS:GO.

-A bunch off people will now give me FLAK saying its in beta and theyll fix everything but most of the things i listed (just a small piece of the cake of whats wrong with this game), are not excusable by beta or alpha or as this game feels a unfinished pre alpha build.

Dear Nexon,
  It is with great regret that I write to you on this day, September 24, 2014, to inform you that you can't mash Combat Arms with Counter Strike and Call of Duty: Black Ops Zombies. I also regret to inform you that I was hoping for better gameplay, but the textrues are as important to you as golf is to teenagers - minus an except few. Now, I applaud your movement towards better gaming titles; however trying to make a Counter Strike knock-off game, isn't the greatest idea.

Sincerely,
  Unhappy Customer

In a nutshell: Another Counter Strike ripoff from Nexon, just with actual Counter Strike maps and models. Stick to Combat Arms if you're into that kind of thing. If not, stick to playing Garry's Mod Zombie servers.
Let us be reminded that its still in BETA. i actually like it. for me, it runs perfectly and i have no problems.

For a beta game, it's pretty enjoyable. I'm loving that valve decided to make a zombie mode for Counter Strike and am really excited for more from this game. I would rate it at 7/10 because of some of the bugs and glitches, but other than that, pretty fun game!
Yes, it might not be a good old CS but has many game modes other than zombies even i like it.

Ok, this is horrible. It's not even half as good as some of the already present CounterStrike mods in the community. Plus, it runs on Source Gold. What. The Fuck. It's. Twenty. Four. Teen. I don't know the situation with Nexon, and I don't want to bother myself searching it up.

3/10

Tried playing a Last Man Standing gamemode. Kinda like Infection from MW3. Every time someone dies it played a global sound of "The Zombies will be back" or another sound alerting  you that a player has been turned to the zombie side. It was way too annoying to play. I turned the sound as far as I could without it muting (using the in game slider) and the game was still too loud and overpowering other computer sounds such as TeamSpeak. The main menu is locked to 1024x768, even if you set the games res to 1920x1080. 

I thought I might enjoy this game because the idea of it sounds fun, but it is not really fun to play. I barely played it mainly because of the sound issue, but the game just isn't that fun. From what I had played, I do not like it.

Well, now that i have wasted an hour of my life playing this game to give a proper review, I will write my review.  PLEASE NOTE: This is a beta review, my complaints could change, but I don't see that happening since this is Nexon we are talking about.  Yes I am aware that this is in beta testing right now, but that is why I reviewing it, to help Nexon (if they choose to do so) fix their game.  ALSO NOTE:  I love Counter-Strike, all of them.  So this negative review is not based on my liking of CS.  Now, on to the review.


For starters, this game is Pay to Win up the booty, which is just not fine for any type of CS title, even if it is created by a different company.  Every weapon you get dissapears after so long, so have fun spending your time on a weapon that will last half as long.

Second is Sounds, and good lordy, are the sounds hilariously bad.  I actually had played this with my friend so I didn"t experience the pain by myself.  While we were playing, we first joined a lobby and were thrown into a cluster-duck of dumb, bland zombie moans, an announcer that sounds infected repeating "the zombies will return" and things similar to that, and a guy on the radio calling in a supply drop, but the guy calling it in sounded like he just had his testicles squished in between to hammers.  In the span of those 5 seconds, I was crying with laughter because of all of the insanity of sounds.

Now for the gameplay, which isn't much better.  Yes, there is a classic mode, which is just CTs against the Ts, but that can't even save this game from the endless and yet almost identical gametypes with zombies.  Just to kill a single zombie, (depending on what game type you are on, on some the zombies are litterally impossible to kill) it takes about 2 clips from an m4, which is way too much to kill a single zombie, as opposed to the zombies' one-hit kill with the secondary melee.  Not exactly fair.  As far as graphics, I don't ever honestly care about graphics, so long as they aren't painful to look at, but unfortunately, I found many textures that were just plain ugly and painful to look at in this game.  I love classic graphics, but there is a difference between classic and just plain bad.  Also, I guess I should mention that there are AI zombie modes, but its like a modded Killing Floor server that gives you too much money, and with really stupid zombie AI, and by "stupid" I mean walking into walls, walking past you, etc.

Wow, my fingers hurt, so I am going to say one more thing, if you like this game, goody for you.  I am not saying it is wrong for a person to like this game.  I mean, this is classic Counter-Strike with zombies!  But sadly, they did everything wrong with the concept of CS with zombies in my opinion.

My final verdict would be a 3/10, since it is free, and it is Counter-Strike, and I wish i could love this game like I wanted to,  but this was just not what I, or many others, wanted.  If Nexon could make this game more like-able, then someone please let me know when they do, I will gladly play this to change my review and update it if it is positively, dramaticly  changed, but this was just a huge let-down.

This game is basically the original Counter Strike, or Condition Zero, with a P2W monetization system thrown in just for the funzies. Although the screenshots for this game show it being played in 1920x1080p, but you don't have to worry, this isn't the case. 

Although you have the regular zombie mode, there is a TDM mode as well. It's somehow not as awful, but it's still bad.

Counter-Strike Nexon: Zombies is still in Beta testing and needs big improvements. It's just another cliche. Its basically a copy of other zombie games such as Left 4 Dead 2/Dead Island. A main aspect that needs working on are the graphics, maps, functions and creativity. The graphics are extremely similar to Counter-Strike Source and the maps are unoriginal. The functions of the game need to be change because humans need to get lots of headshot to kill a zombie and there are countless numbers of zombies running around everywhere that can infect humans within a single claw strike. When a claw strike attack is used it can infect about one metre infront. The zombies side is clearly overpowered. It takes about 10 people to continously headshot the zombie for 15 seconds with a machine gun to kill it. 
Overall, i think this game needs working on and is absolutly shit. Fortunately, its free to play. The servers have a shitload of lag and the response of the server is horrific.

Other than that the game is CS 1.6 for free with an optional zombie mode on the side.

Also, if you have to leave the game (it was after two rounds of boss fight, both of them lost, and then it was restarted by another player AGAIN), you won't get any rewards or EXP, only some penalty points. Not the way to keep players motivated.

As Nexon is completely known in the F2P world they have now come with a F2P 'Counter-Strike'
Okay you have the normal missions like Defuse on Dust_2... But then they also came with this 'Zombie' mode.
The zombies in the game are quite balanced and they can be killed quite fast. The only thing that I can't stand about the game is that the aiming function and the customisation into the crosshair just totally blows... Also because of Nexon you get these wierd guns that you can buy/grind and they will do more damage of have less recoil.. I think this game does not deserve the name 'Counter-Strike'. I didnt got any disconnection problems though. I will stick to CS:GO and possibly will play again in the future.

Edit:
If you are used to CS:GO/CS:S, don't even try to play this.
You can craft overpowered weapons that have more accurate,ammo,damage.
Rooms are full of hackers ALREADY! (and old 1.6 players)
Hit detection is also pretty crap and should be fixed.
Still no customisation for the crosshairs which is also crap.
Zombie mode is still in favour to the Zombies cause they have INSANE amount of health and you get not enough bullets to PewPew all of these zombies.
So my end conclusion to this Pay2Win (game)
SKIP IT > BUY CS:GO
